bestBHT.bht: In the days between the Ascension and Pentecost, the number of believers had increased as the disciples gathered around the Apostles. The Holy Ghost was stirring in Peter, the leading spirit of the infant community, and many of the disciples who had seen the risen Lord remained in Galilee. The term names refers to the number of individuals, and it is likely that a multitude, about 120 people, were gathered together.

Henry Alford: In the days between the Ascension and Pentecost: during which it appears that the number of the assembly had increased, not probably by fresh conversions, but by the gathering round the Apostles of those who had previously been disciples."
The number of names, that is, of persons: but the term would hardly be used except where the number is small.
We surely may answer, 'not in Jerusalem.'
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: in those days—of expectant prayer, and probably towards the close of them, when the nature of their future work began more clearly to dawn upon them"
the Holy Ghost, already 'breathed' on the Eleven, was stirring in Peter, who was to be the leading spirit of the infant community
Many, therefore, of the 'five hundred brethren' who saw their risen Lord 'at once,' must have remained in Galilee.
Albert Barnes: Peter standing up, or rising... It is not improbable, besides, that Peter was the most aged of the apostles; and from his uniform conduct we know that he was the most ardent."
The number of the names - The number of the persons, or individuals. The word 'name' is often used to denote 'the person'..."
This settles the question that the election of a minister and pastor should be by the church, and that a pastor should not be placed over a church by a patron, or by an ecclesiastical body.
Marvin Vincent: Of the disciples. The best texts read brethren."
There was a multitude of persons gathered together, about, etc."
Oclov, multitude, would not be used of a number about to be stated.
John Calvin: It was meet that Matthias should be chosen into the place of Judas, lest, through the treachery of one man, all that might seem to have been made of none effect which Christ had once appointed.
The preaching of the gospel both have had, and also have, less credit at this day, if the beginning thereof had been imperfect.
Surely it seemeth to me a thing more like to be true, that Luke doth in this place express the number of them, that we may know that they were all gathered together when Peter made this sermon.
Philip Schaff: Various reasons have been suggested for this priority which St. Peter certainly possessed among his brother apostles.
He earned this priority by his ready confession of faith in Christ.
Peter in the early Church, from this age, from the personal friendship he had enjoyed with his Master, no doubt occupied one of the chief positions.
Archibald T. Robertson: This Hebraistic use of ονομα=person occurs in the LXX and in Revelation 3:4; Revelation 11:13."

The word 'gathered' is not in the Greek here, but it does occur in Matthew 22:34 and that is undoubtedly the idea in Luke 17:35 as in Acts 2:1; Acts 2:44; Acts 2:47; 1 Corinthians 11:20; 1 Corinthians 14:23. So also here."
A crowd for 'the upper room.' No special significance in the number 120, just the number there.
John Gill: and there was there a company whose names and wills agreed in this same opinion
they were all in one place, and of the same mind
who not only gave themselves to the Lord, but to one another, by the will of God
John Wesley: The number of persons together — Who were together in the upper room.
were a hundred and twenty — But he had undoubtedly many more in other places;
of whom more than five hundred saw him at once after his resurrection, 1 Corinthians 15:6.

bhtAttempts.bht: In the days between the Ascension and Pentecost, the number of believers had increased as the disciples gathered around the Apostles. These were the days of expectant prayer, when the nature of their future work began to dawn upon them. The Holy Ghost was stirring in Peter, the leading spirit of the infant community, and many of the disciples who had seen the risen Lord remained in Galilee. The term names refers to the number of individuals, and it is likely that a multitude, about 120 people, were gathered together for this important occasion. This gathering of believers set the foundation for the preaching of the gospel, establishing an imperfect beginning that would credit the preaching with less credibility later on. The unity and oneness of the believers is evident, as they not only gave themselves to the Lord, but also to one another. The number 120 holds no special significance, but it was important that Matthias was chosen into the place of Judas to ensure the continuing fulfillment of Christ's appointed work.

In the days between the Ascension and Pentecost, the number of believers had increased as the disciples gathered around the Apostles. These were the days of expectant prayer, when the nature of their future work began to dawn upon them. The Holy Ghost was stirring in Peter, the leading spirit of the infant community, and many of the disciples who had seen the risen Lord remained in Galilee. The term names refers to the number of individuals, and it is likely that a multitude, about 120 people, were gathered together for this important occasion.

The term names refers to the number of individuals, and it is likely that a multitude, about 120 people, were gathered together for this important occasion. This gathering of believers set the foundation for the preaching of the gospel, establishing an imperfect beginning that would credit the preaching with less credibility later on.

In the days between the Ascension and Pentecost, the number of believers had increased as the disciples gathered around the Apostles. The Holy Ghost was stirring in Peter, the leading spirit of the infant community, and many of the disciples who had seen the risen Lord remained in Galilee. The term names refers to the number of individuals, and it is likely that a multitude, about 120 people, were gathered together.

In the days between the Ascension and Pentecost, the number of believers had increased as the disciples gathered around the Apostles. These were the days of expectant prayer, and towards the end of this period, the nature of their future work began to become clearer. The Holy Ghost was stirring in Peter, who was to be the leading spirit of the community. Many of the disciples who had witnessed the risen Lord had remained in Galilee. The term names here refers to the number of individuals, and it is likely that about 120 people were gathered together for this significant occasion.
